option.name: description
option.value:
This "course" contains the interactive lab exercises for the CS1026 labs for the fall term, 2017 for both Sections 001 and 002. These exercises make use of PyCharm version 2. Within the "course" done with PyCharm, you will find "labs" and within each lab you will find a number of "tasks". The tasks are done within PyCharm. Instructions on how to download the "course" and initiate it in PyCharm can be found on the course website.
Descriptions of each lab AND the description of a lab programming exercise can be found in the course website. Please make sure to read the description and the exercise before coming to lab.

entry.value: Simple task to print something.

option.name: text
option.value:
# Replace placeholders with correct Python
function("I am learning Python")

entry.value:
Let's try some simple Arithmetic add 3 and 5 and store it in the variable "answer".

The + operator can be used to add two numbers together.
Place the proper variable name in the print function as well.

option.name: text
option.value:

answer = 3+5 print(replace_me)

entry.value: Lets practice all of it together.

option.name: text
option.value:

print("My first python code") replace_1 = 46*2 replace_2 = 3+5
print(answer1) print(answer2)
print("Everything works")

entry.value:
Let's take a look at some operator precedence.

Add a line after the last one to check an example for yourself.

# Try the following Python and answer the questions
x=7 print(x+5) print((x+5)*3) print(x+5*3) # Why are the last two different?
print(Add 1 to x and divide the sum by 4)

entry.value:
Let's take a look at some boolean expressions.

Python has boolean expressions just like you would use in math.

The standard ones are:
> (greater than),
< (less than),
<= (less than or equal to),
>= (greater than or equal to),
== (equal (note the 2 equal signs!),
!= (not equal).

Add your own line after the ones listed to try some yourself.

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: Add 3 to x and see if the sum is greater than 7

option.name: text
option.value:
# Try the following Python and answer the questions
x = 2 print(2<5) print(x<=2) print(2!=5) print(x==2)# 2 equals signs checks equality of something one equals sign is an assignment operator
#try printing 2=2 #delete the # in the line below to uncomment and test it #print(2=2)
print(Add 3 to x and see if the sum is greater than 7) #add your own!

entry.value:
Let's take a look at strings and concatenation of them.

Notice that you can use the + operator to add (or concatenate) two strings together.

Try adding a line to test concatenating strings together for yourself.

option.name: text
option.value:
# Try the following Python and answer the questions
print("CS" + "1026") print("CS" + " "+ "1026") print("CS "+"1026") # notice the space differences
# for the print function you can also use the ','; try the following: print(String 1,String 2)
# try your own

entry.value:
Let's take a look at formatting strings for output.

There are two basic ways to format strings.
The first is called interpolation and uses a % followed by a conversion type.
The basic conversion types that you may want to remember are:
d - signed integer decimal.
f - floating point decimal.
s - string.

A full list can be found in your text or
here: https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#printf-style-string-formatting

The second way for format strings calls a format function where
each set of braces {} represents an argument to be formatted.
They can be left as {} OR you can number them {0} {1} for readability.

Try adding your own example to the code!

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: Try your own formatted print here

option.name: text
option.value:
# Try the following Python code and answer the questions
# Lets try some simple formatting name= "Sterling Archer" age = 36
# Two ways of formatting strings # The first is called interpolation in this case %s represents a string and is the first element # %d represents an integer and is the second element in the list print("%s %d" % (name, age))
# The second method calls a format function. # It replaces the {} with the variables in the format function in order. print("{}{}".format(name,age))
# Print the following string and integer variables using the interpolation method course = "CS1026a" year = 2016 print("%s %d" Format symbol and variables)
Try your own formatted print here

entry.value:
Let's take a look at how we assign values to variables.

Remember the left hand side of the assignment operator is what is
receiving the value (the variable) and the right hand side is what is giving the value.

You can reuse and reassign variables after you have declared them at least once.

Try at least one of your own examples before continuing.

option.name: possibleAnswer
option.value: # Print the variable that you just assigned a value to.

option.name: text
option.value:
# Try the Python below and complete the placeholders.
x = 7 print(x)
y = x+5 print("x is {} and y is {}".format(x,y))
x = x+5 # Note the value changes when we do the statement above print("x is now {}".format(x))
y = x+5 # If we repeat the second print what will we get? print("x is {} and y is {}".format(x,y))
An assignment to a variable Print the variable

entry.value:
Let's take a look at a few more examples of what we have already done.

Notice how we can pass in an arithmetic expression to the format
function by surrounding it in ().

Try it for yourself!

Remember that Python will always try to maintain as much precision as possible.

Notice how the two print statements produce different results.
The second one is calling a function int() to convert the result to an integer value.

Finally there are escape sequences you can use in strings.
For example, \n adds a new line, \\ places a '\' in your string, \" a double quote, \' a single quote.

Try some examples for yourself before continuing

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: Print the variable 'a' using a format

option.name: text
option.value:
# Try the Python below and answer the questions.
# Wwe assign some variables and check an expression. # Note how we checked the expression with format x = -1 y = 0 print("Is it true that x <= y?") print("It's {}!".format((x<=y)))
a = 2.52 b = 5 # Notice how these two print statements give different results. Why is that? print(a*b) print(int(a*b))
print("She said, hey there") # Note how you can use escape sequences to format your strings as well print("He said,\n hey there")
print(Print the variable 'a' using a format) # Add your own

entry.value:
Let's write a small program to take input from the keyboard and use it to convert celsius to fahrenheit.

We can use the input function to gather input from the keyboard and store it in a variable. The string we pass to the input function is the prompt displayed to the user.

Make sure you store it as the proper value type or convert it after you take the input otherwise it may not work.

Fix the print statement to continue.

option.name: text
option.value:
# Fix the print statement in the following Python program and then run it.
# Note how to get input from the keyboard celsius = float(input("Please enter the Celsius value: ")) # Notice how we had to cast celsius to float try removing the float cast and see what happens. # When you take a value from input it is a string value by default. # Therefore you must convert it to whatever other type of value if you to. # In this case we convert it to a "float" value.
# Note 1.8 is 9/5 # fDegrees stores the Fahrenheit value fDegrees = (celsius * 1.8 )+ 32 print(replace_me)

entry.value:
We will now write a small program to do the opposite of the previous task.

This program will take a fahrenheit value from a user and convert it to celsius.

The formula to do this conversion is C = (F-32) * 5/9; you will need to express this as a Python expression.

When finished try it with 86 Fahrenheit it should output 30.0 Celsius.

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: Expression to conver from F to C

option.name: text
option.value:
# Complete the placeholders in the following to finish the program
fDegrees = float(input("Please enter the Fahrenheit value: "))
# Convert to celsius Variable for the celsius value = Expression to conver from F to C print(Variable to print the answer)

entry.value:
If statements allow your code to branch depending on a condition.

Remember from lecture that the if statement is structured as follows:
if conditional:
     do something
elif condtional:
     do something
else:
        do something

An if statement can have as many else-ifs (elif) as needed.
An if statement does not even need to end with an else clause.
Recall also from lecture the boolean operators, some of these in python are >, <, <=, >=, == .

Complete the program. The variable x is set to 5.
Finish it so that the program executes and print a message when x is larger than 5.

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: Print a message when x is greater than 5

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: Print a message when x is not greater than 5

option.name: possibleAnswer
option.value: "X is smaller than or equal to 5"

option.name: text
option.value:
# Replace the placeholders and run the Python program.
x=5
# Is x > 5? Type in the if-part print(Print a message when x is greater than 5) else: print(Print a message when x is not greater than 5)

entry.value:
To familiarize yourself with boolean expressions, fix the following expressions by changing the '?'s so that each of the print statements prints out True.

Recall that in Python the operators for AND, OR and NOT are the keywords 'and' 'or' and 'not'.

That is to say... if you wanted to check 'if a and b' were true and do something if they were True, you would write:
and if a and b:
     do something

option.name: text
option.value:
# Replace the '?'s with the correct boolean or relational operator to make all the statements True
a = 12 b = 7 t = True c = 'e'
print((a > 0) boolean operator 1 (b > 0))
print(('a' > c) boolean operator 2 ('E' != c))
print((a % b != 0) and (b * 2 relational operator a))
print((t boolean operator 3 not(a > b)) and t)

entry.value:
In this task we will give you code that is storing the current hour of the day.
You need to complete (fill in placeholders) the statements provided to create a program so that if the hour is before 12 noon, then the program will print:

  "Good morning, world!"

or if the hour is after 12 noon and before 6pm (18) it prints:

  "Good afternoon, world!"

and, finally, if the hour is after 6pm it prints:

  "Good evening, world!"


We have provided you with the variable hour set properly to the hour.

We have also provided the basic structure of the if-elif-else and the print statement which uses the variable timeOfDay.

You must set the variable timeOfDay in your if and else if and else statements
to "morning", "afternoon", or "evening".

Have your TA check your code for this one.

option.name: text
option.value:
# Add statements to complete the program.
from datetime import datetime hour = datetime.now().hour
if First condition: Assignment 1 elif Second condition: Assignment 2 else: Assignment 3
# Place your code here
print("Good {}, world".format(timeOfDay))

entry.value:
In this program, we will write code that has one loop and does different computations each time through the loop depending on the value of the loop variable.

The program should inputsa name from the keyboard and then print out the name
every third time through the loop.

The program should print a random integer between 1 and 10 every other time through the loop. It should also print out the string "test" and the loop variable every time through the loop. The loop should run 20 times.
This is the last task; be sure to tell your TA you are finished also make sure your code completes the tasks properly

[Hint: use the modulo operator %]

option.name: text

print(addNumbers(223,1235))

entry.value:
The factorial of a number is that number multiplied by each of it's predecessors until you reach 0.

For example 3!(read as 3 factorial) is 3x2x1 = 6.
5! is 5x4x3x2x1 = 120

You are to complete the definition of a function that computes the factorial of a given number.

We have given you a small program that tries to call a function called factorial for the numbers 5,7, and 9.

option.name: text
option.value:
# Replace the placeholders and complete the Python program.
def factorial(n): result = n for Complete the for loop statement: Compute a new result value return result
print(factorial(5)) print(factorial(7)) print(factorial(9))

The first function simply prints "Hello World"; it will be called 'helloWorld'.

The second function will call 'helloWorld' n times. It will be called 'helloWorldNTimes'.

We have given you the main function that will call helloWorldNTimes for you

option.name: text
option.value:

def Define "helloWorld" function name and parameters: Add print statement
def helloWorldNTimes(n): Enter the for statement: Call "helloWorld"
# Include a "main" function def main(): helloWorldNTimes(7)
# Call the main function main()

entry.value:
In this task you must write a function that takes a number and checks to see if 7 is a multiple of it. It will return the number if it is, otherwise it will return -1.

For example, 6 is not a multiple of 7, 7 is a multiple of 7 as well as 14,21,... Thus if you ran your function on 14 it will return 14. If you ran it on 6 it will return -1

We have created a function for you that will check your function for all numbers between 0-100 not inclusive.

option.name: text

entry.value:
In this lab you will be reinforcing concepts from class on lists, including how to make and modify them as well as how to use some of their methods.

In this first task, we have set up a function stub for you and the main method.
Your task is to finish the function so that it returns the number of strings in the list passed to it that have more than 2 letters.

Recall from class the len function and how to loop through the list.

option.name: text
option.value:
# Replace the placeholders and complete the Python program.
def moreThanTwo (Parameter that is the list): count=0 for Complete the for: if Compete the if: count+=1 return count
# Create a list of words words=["hello","good","nice","as","at","baseball","absorb","sword","a","tall","so","bored","silver", "hi","pool","we","I","am","seven","Do","you","want","ants","because","that's","how","you","get"]
# Call the function and print the number of words with more than two letters. print(moreThanTwo(words))

In this task we give you some lists. You are to write a function called someSame.

This function will take two lists and return true if at least one identical element is in each list and will return false otherwise.

def someSameDefine the parameters: for Complete the for that loops through list one.: for Complete the for that loops through list two.: if Test for equality of two elements from the lists: return True return False
# Define some lists of numbers someNumbers = [1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9,0] someOtherNumbers = [11,22,33,44,55,66,77,88,99,100]
# See if these two lists have one element the same print(someSame(someNumbers,someOtherNumbers))
# Define another list someMoreNumbers = [111,222,333,444,555,6,777,888,999,1000] # Check the new list and one of the others print(someSame(someNumbers,someMoreNumbers))

So if the list we gave you was lista = ["pool","hammer"] the list your function should return would consist of the values 4 and 6 in that order, i.e. a list [4,6].

# Define a list of words words = ["hello","good","nice","as","at","baseball","absorb","sword","a","tall","so","bored","silver","hi" ,"pool","we","I","am","seven","Do","you","want","ants","because","that's","how","you","get"]
# Print the list of the lengths of the words print(lenWords(words))

entry.value:
Recall concatenation of lists from class. In this task we give you a list of words.

Write a function zFirst that returns the words in a list sorted BUT with all words that begin with z at the front. You should use Python's internal sort() function.

So if the list of words is ['a','b','c','za'] the resulting list should be ['za','a','b','c']. It is not expected that you keep the original list intact.

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: Add test to determine if word begins with a 'z'

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: Sort the other list of words

option.name: text
option.value:
# Replace the placeholders and complete the Python program.
def zFirst(words): # We will need two lists zresult =[] result =[] for word in words: if Add test to determine if word begins with a 'z': # If it does, add it to the first list Add to list of z-words else: # Does not begin with a 'z' Append to other list
Sort the list of z-words Sort the other list of words Define what to return
# Define a list of words words=["hello","good","nice","as","at","baseball","absorb","sword","a","tall","so","bored","silver", "hi","pool","we","am","seven","do","you","want","ants","because","that's","how","you","get", "zebra","zealot","zoo","xylophone","asparagus"]
# Print the result of using zFirst print(zFirst(words))

entry.value:
In this lab we will focus on reading and writing from files.

For the first task, open the file text.txt and print out each line. For example, if the file contains 3 lines and line 1 is 'a', line 2 is 'b' and line 3 is 'c' your program should print the following out:
a
b
c

Be sure to use print with 'end = ""' as there are already new line characters. You can also strip the new line as was shown in class.

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: Loop through each line of the file

option.name: text
option.value:
# Replace the placeholders and run the Python program.
text = Open the file "text.txt" for reading for Loop through each line of the file: print(Print each line) text.close()

option.name: text
option.value: Computer programming studies are one of the major global trends. Python is currently the most popular language used to teach programming for beginners. To promote effective, easily accessible programming education, we at JetBrains, are committed to providing quality, professional, seamless solutions for learning programming with Python, keeping the needs of both novice programmers and educators in mind.

entry.value:
In this task, we give you a file called text.txt, we also open a new file for you called myfile.txt.

There is only one line in text.txt. The program should read this line and split it
into individual words; these words should be written to the screen and to the
file myfile.txt with each word on its own line.

Hint: a similar example was done in the lecture notes for you.

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: Split the line into separate words

option.name: text
option.value:
# Replace the placeholders and complete the program.
text = open("text.txt","r") myfile =open("myfile.txt","w") line = Get the line words = Split the line into separate words for word in words: print(word) Write to file)
# Close the files Close the file for text.txt Close the file for myfile.txt

option.name: text
option.value: This is a file with this single line of words.

entry.value:
For this task we give you a "comma separated values" file (so-called csv-file)
called filmdata.csv. A csv file is a file that can be used to store data in columns and rows, such as in a spreadsheet.

Each line contains data separated by the comma character ","; each row is ended by a new line character. In this particular csv file, the first data entry of each line is a year and the third entry in the line is the title of a film.

Process the file by printing the year AND the title of the film separated by a space BUT only for lines where the year is BEFORE 1990. For example, the first line
that meets the criteria would be:

1983,104,The Dead Zone,Horror,"Walken, Christopher","Adams, Brooke","Cronenberg, David",79,No
and what should be printed would be:

1983 The Dead Zone

Note that the open of the file filmdata.csv makes use of 'encoding="utf-8"'. This is often necessary for files that come from the web or other sources. UTF-8 is a character encoding that is used to represent any character in the Unicode standard. UTF-8 is the preferred encoding for e-mail and web pages.

option.name: text

entry.value:
In this lab we will be reinforcing the idea of exceptions. Recall from class that exceptions are a construct that allow you as the programmer to elegantly handle issues that may or may arise from running your code as opposed to just crashing. By using exceptions you can create programs that may allow a user to understand what they did wrong so they can fix it in the future instead providing just a simple general error message.

In this first task you are given code to attempt to open a file, however this file does not exist. Surround it in a try statement that has an except clause that catches the IO error and prints a message to the user.

option.name: text
option.value:
# Replace the placeholders with code to handle the exception and run the Python program
Your code f=open("thefile.file","r") Your code for the exception: Print a message

entry.value:
Recall the from the notes the 'finally' clause of a try statement. This clause allows you to execute code regardless of whether or not there is an exception thrown. In this exercise we have given you a loop: the first time through the loop there is an error because of an attempted division by zero. However, we still want to print to the user that the loop executed.

Add a try statement in the loop that has an except clause AND a finally clause. The except clause should print a message to the user informing them that a division by zero was attempted. The finally clause should print out how many times we have been through the loop.

option.name: possibleAnswer
option.value: print("On iteration",i," tried to divide by zero!")

option.name: text
option.value:
# Replace the placeholders with code to handle the exception with the finnally clause and run the Python program
for i in range(10): try: print(7/i) Except clause: Exception message Finally clause Finally message

entry.value:
Other then just catching exceptions you can also raise them yourself with a raise statement.

In this task we assume a user has given us some values which we stored in the list 'values'. We have hardcoded some values for you in the list 'values'.

Loop through the values in the list. Place the statement 'print("the value is :",values[cur])' in the first placeholder. If the value is a string raise a ValueError that says "This is a string!"

Note: you'll notice that once the exception is raised the execution of the program stops.

To check if the value is a string you can use 'if type(values[cur]) == str'.

Run the program a few times; notice how the output is a little different sometimes.

Why?

option.name: text

entry.value:
Recall from class the concepts of sets and dictionaries. This lab will cover both.

In this task we will work with sets, we have created 3 sets for you listing some characters from the original 3 Star Wars movies. Create a new set called unEps that contains the union of all the characters in episode4, episode5 and episode6

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: Compute the union of the three sets

option.name: text

entry.value:
Recall from lecture notes the operations for intersection and difference of sets.

In this task, we use the same lists we had from task 1. Intersect episodes 4 and 5 THEN difference episode 6 with the intersection you created. Call this final set 'final'.

option.name: text

entry.value:
Let's move on to dictionaries.

Remember from class that dictionaries are a way to store values with unique keys. For this task we are going to give you a sentence. For each word in the sentence check to see if that word exists in the dictionary. If it does replace it with the value from the dictionary. (Hint... use split.) Also remember to add back spaces when you add the words to the new string.

When you are finished, print out the new sentence. You can loop through the list created by split and add the word to the newstring then add a space.

Loop through a sorted version of that dictionary. Print out the name, followed by a space, followed by a colon, followed by a space, then finally the alias.
Eg. Stirling : Duchess

entry.value:
So far we have been working with JUST a dictionary or JUST a set.

However, in Python we can combine these together (and lists) to create more complex structures. In this task we are going to ask you to make a dictionary of sets.

The dictionary needs to have sets for the following:
    - Dictionary entry 'even' will have the set of all even numbers from 0-20.
    - Dictionary entry 'odd' will have the set of all odd numbers from 1-20.
    - Dictionary entry 'three' will have the set of all multiples of 3 from 1-20.
    - Dictionary entry 'prime' will have the set of all primes from 0-20.

It is up to you how to determine these. HOWEVER, we did provide a function to check if a number is prime.

This lab is focused on classes.

Recall from lecture how to call a constructor to create an object. We have provided the class 'Banana' for you. Each time a banana is created the variable 'bananaID' is incremented.

Create 2 bananas 'b1' and 'b2' where indicated.

option.name: text

entry.value:
For this task, create a class 'Dinosaur' with an instance variable called _type.

Create a getter method called getType() that returns the dinosaur's type.

Create a setter method called setType() that sets its type.

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: Define the parameters for the method

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: Define the parameters for the method

option.name: text
option.value:
# Replace the placeholders with code and run the Python program
class Dinosaur: def __init__(self): Initialize the instance variable _type
def setTypeDefine the parameters for the method: Set the type
def getTypeDefine the parameters for the method: Get the type
# Create three dinsosaurs d1 = Dinosaur() d2 = Dinosaur() d3 = Dinosaur()
# Set their types d1.setType("T-Rex") d2.setType("Velociraptor") d3.setType("Stegosaurus")
# Print the types print(d1.getType()) print(d2.getType()) print(d3.getType())

entry.value:
This lab is on inheritance.

In this task, you are to create a class named 'Fruit'. In the constructor create instance variables for the shape and colour.

Define a method called 'canBePhone' that returns a string that says "fruits can't be phones..." Create a class 'Banana' whose superclass is 'Fruit'. Override the 'canBePhone' method to return "Ring ring ring ring ring ring ring banana phone\nBoop-boo-ba-doo-ba-doop"

Create some instances of each class to test to make sure you have done it correctly.

Verify the validity of your answers.

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: Create the class definition header for the class Banana

option.name: text
option.value:
# Replace the placeholders with code and run the Python program
# Define class Fruit class Fruit(): def __init__(self): Initialization statement 1 Initialization statement 2 self._shape=""
def Define header for 'canBePhone' method: return "fruits can't be phones..."
# Define class Banana Create the class definition header for the class Banana: def __init__(self): Define the initilization
def Override the method: return "Ring ring ring ring ring ring ring banana phone\nBoop-boo-ba-doo-ba-doop"
apple=Fruit() print(apple.canBePhone()) banana=Banana() print(banana.canBePhone())

entry.value:
In this task, we will continue with our class 'Fruit'.

In the constructor for the class 'Fruit', we will create instance variables for the colour, shape, and taste; these should all be strings.

We define a method called 'descriptor' that returns a string that describes the fruit; it should use the instance variables for the description

Create classes 'Banana' and 'Apple' whose superclass is 'Fruit'. For the class 'Apple' include an attribute that describes the type of apple, also a string. In the class 'Apple' override the method 'descriptor' to return a description of the apple with the type of the apple added to the descriptor produced from the class 'Fruit'.

Some instances of each class are provided to test the methods.

entry.value:
In this task, we will create a class called 'Automobile'. It will have the following instance variables:
    - 'doors', the number of doors (in Integer),.
    - 'color', color of the automobile (a String).

A class 'SportsCar' is defined as a subclass of of 'Automobile'. It has an additional attribute 'engine' which is the size of the engine in horsepower (an Integer).

The class 'SportsCar' has a subclass 'Convertible' with an attribute 'top' (a String), which describes the type of convertible (soft top or hard top).

Each of the classes 'SportsCar' and 'Convertible' have their own display methods. The display method in 'SportsCar' should use the display method in 'Automobile', but override it. The display method in 'Automobile' should use the display method in 'SportsCar', but should override it.

Complete the specification of the classes and the definition of the methods.

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: Use the constructor in the super class

option.name: placeholderText
option.value: Use the constructor from the super class

option.name: text
